title: Hawaii Big Island is Under a Tropical Storm Warning as Hone Threatens Floods and Fires – The Yeshiva World
message:
A tropical storm warning was in effect for the Big Island, and a red flag fire warning was issued for the leeward sides of all islands through 6 p.m. on Saturday.
The National Weather Service issues the alert when warm temperatures, very low humidity and stronger winds combine to raise fire dangers.
The winds are expected to be strongest where they blow downslope from higher terrain, over headlands and through passes, the hurricane center advised.
Firefighters remained on the scene of a small blaze that started Friday night in Waikoloa, on the dry side of the Big Island, according to Big Island Mayor Mitch Roth.
The eastern and southeastern parts of the Big Island could get 5 to 10 inches (11 to 25 centimeters) of rain.

title: Tropical Storm Hone steadily approaches Hawaii , threatening floods and fires
message:
A tropical storm warning was in effect for the Big Island, and a red flag fire warning was issued for the leeward sides of all islands through 6 p.m. on Saturday.
Firefighters remained on the scene of a small blaze that started Friday night in Waikoloa, on the dry side of the Big Island, according to Big Island Mayor Mitch Roth.
Officials were closing some Big Island beach parks in anticipation of dangerously high surf and preparing to open shelters if needed, Roth said.
The eastern and southeastern parts of the Big Island could get 11 to 25 centimetres of rain.
Moving westward across the Pacific behind Hone was Hurricane Gilma, which strengthened to Category 3 status Saturday afternoon far from land.

title: Tropical Storm Hone steadily approaches Hawaii , threatening floods and fires

title: Tropical Storm Hone steadily approaches Hawaii , threatening floods and fires - Medicine Hat NewsMedicine Hat News
message:
Tropical Storm Hone steadily approaches Hawaii, threatening floods and firesBy Audrey Mcavoy And Jennifer Sinco Kelleher, The Associated Press on August 24, 2024.
Firefighters remained on the scene of a small blaze that started Friday night in Waikoloa, on the dry side of the Big Island, according to Big Island Mayor Mitch Roth.
Officials were closing some Big Island beach parks in anticipation of dangerously high surf and preparing to open shelters if needed, Roth said.
The eastern and southeastern parts of the Big Island could get 5 to 10 inches (11 to 25 centimeters) of rain.
Moving westward across the Pacific behind Hone was Hurricane Gilma, which strengthened to Category 3 status Saturday afternoon far from land.

title: Hawaiʻi Island under tropical storm warning as Hone threatens floods and fires
message:
A tropical storm warning remained in effect for the Big Island at 6 p.m. Saturday.
The National Weather Service issues the alert when warm temperatures, very low humidity and stronger winds combine to raise fire dangers.
But while Hone presents high fire dangers, "it's not on the magnitude of that," weather service meteorologist Derek Wroe in Honolulu said Saturday.
The island could get sustained winds of 20 to 40 mph and gusts near 60 mph, weather officials said.
Moving westward across the Pacific behind Hone was Hurricane Gilma, which strengthened to Category 3 status Saturday afternoon far from land.

title: Tropical Storm Hone steadily approaches Hawaii , threatening floods and fires
message:
This image provided by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration shows Tropical Storm Hone as it continues to track to the west toward the Hawaiian Islands, Saturday, Aug. 24, 2024.
(National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration via AP)

title: Tropical Storm Hone prompts warnings for Hawaii Big Island
message:
Tropical Storm Hon on Saturday near Hawaii’s Big Island with maximum sustained winds of 65 mph, forecasters said.
Hon’s center was 185 miles southeast of Hilo Saturday afternoon and moving west at 15 mph, the National Hurricane Center said.
Tropical Storm Hone is forecast to pass near or south of the island Saturday night into early Sunday morning.
Steady rain was falling on the Big Island Saturday afternoon and is expected to intensify and threaten flash flooding, the weather service office in Honolulu said.
Residents of the Big Island could see 6 to 12 inches of rain, it said.

title: Here Timing For Severe Thunderstorms With Drenching Downpours That Could Cause Flooding
message:
Strong winds, dangerous storm surges, and life-threatening flooding are expected to continue in Bermuda during the day.
The weekend's first half will be cloudy, with a high temperature of around 80 degrees on Saturday.
The chance for showers will continue overnight, with thunderstorms also possible.
Storms will become likely starting early in the afternoon Sunday on another mostly cloudy day with a high temperature again around 80 degrees.
The high temperature will be in the low 70s.

title: Light earthquake : M4 . 4 quake has struck near María Elena in Chile
message:
A light earthquake magnitude 4.4 (ml/mb) has occurred on Sunday, 67 km S of María Elena, Chile (42 miles).
A tsunami warning has not been issued (Does not indicate if a tsunami actually did or will exist).
The earthquake was roughly at a depth of 72.848 km (45 miles).
Exact location of earthquake, longitude -69.7748 West, latitude -22.9477 South, depth = 72.848 km.
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Date-Time, Location, Distances, Parameters and details about this quake, recorded: 67 km S of María Elena, Chile.

title: Light earthquake : M4 . 6 quake has struck near Kepulauan Babar , Indonesia
message:
A light earthquake with magnitude 4.6 (ml/mb) was detected on Sunday, Kepulauan Babar, Indonesia (0 miles).
Exact location of earthquake, 129.7039° East, -7.0784° South, depth 144.875 km.
The epicenter of the earthquake was roughly 144.875 km (90 miles) below the earth’s surface.
Every year there are an estimated 13,000 light earthquakes in the world.
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Date-Time, Location, Distances, Parameters and details about this quake, recorded: Kepulauan Babar, Indonesia.

title: Light earthquake 4 . 2 mag , 30 km SE of Jurm , Afghanistan
message:
A light earthquake magnitude 4.2 (ml/mb) has struck on Saturday, 30 kilometers (19 miles) from Jurm in Afghanistan.
The epicenter was at a depth of 219.338 km (136 miles).
The epicenter was 66 km (41 miles) from Fayzabad (c. 44 400 pop), 54 km (33 miles) from Ishqoshim (c. 26 000 pop), 46 km (29 miles) from Ashkāsham (c. 12 100 pop), 30 km (19 miles) from Jurm (c. 12 100 pop).
Nearby country/countries, Afghanistan (c. 29 121 000 pop), Tajikistan (c. 7 487 000 pop) (That might be effected).
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Date-Time, Location, Distances, Parameters and details about this quake, recorded: 30 km SE of Jurm, Afghanistan.

title: Japanese government to develop AI - equipped drones to identify suspicious people in disaster - hit areas
message:
TOKYO: The government plans to develop a drone equipped with artificial intelligence and cameras that can automatically identify suspicious people when flying over disaster-hit areas.
The government intends to use AI-equipped drones to supplement police patrols and strengthen crime prevention measures in disaster areas.
Private security companies and others have already developed and tested AI-equipped drones.
The government plans to deploy its own AI-equipped drones to survey disaster areas as soon as possible and is also considering utilising private sector technology.
Some of the drones developed by the private sector include autonomous drones that automatically track suspicious persons after detecting them.

title: String Of Storms Could Develop As Height Of Hurricane Season Nears - Here Timing : AccuWeather
message:
“We could see a parade of storms developing during September," AccuWeather Lead Hurricane Expert Alex DaSilva.
"There’s a possibility that we could see multiple tropical storms and hurricanes in the Atlantic basin on the same day, similar to the frequency of storms we’ve seen during other supercharged hurricane seasons like 2020."
The 2024 hurricane season, which began Saturday, Jun 1, runs through Saturday, Nov 30.
The statistical peak of the hurricane season is traditionally around the middle of September, which AccuWeather says could be "supercharged" this year.
Although hurricanes often make headlines for their destructive wind gusts when they make landfall, AccuWeather meteorologists are noting that storms are creating bigger impacts that reach farther inland.

title: Hawaii on alert for Tropical Storm Hone , extreme heat travels across country
message:
(NEW YORK) — Hawaii is on alert for Tropical Storm Hone while extreme heat is expected to expand from the South to the Midwest, leaving 25 million Americans under heat alerts this weekend.
A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the Big Island of Hawaii as Tropical Storm Hone passes by to the south of the islands.
In terms of wind, tropical storm force winds are forecast to begin this evening and throughout the overnight hours into Sunday morning.
Hone may reach hurricane status for a short period of time as it passes south of Hawaii, but it is forecast to stay over open water and eventually weaken back into a Tropical Storm.
The extreme heat drifts north over the next few days, heading through the central plains and into the upper Midwest.

title: National News - Media One Radio Group ( WWSE | WJTN | WHUG | WKSN | WQFX
message:
A Tropical Storm Warning is in effect for the Big Island of Hawaii as Tropical Storm Hone passes by to the south of the islands.
While it won’t be a direct hit, the storm is still close enough to deliver some potentially dangerous impacts.
The main threat is for heavy rain that could cause flash flooding and landslides, especially on the eastern side of the Big Island where rainfall totals of 5 to 10 inches are possible.
In terms of wind, tropical storm force winds are forecast to begin this evening and throughout the overnight hours into Sunday morning.
Gusts will generally be in the 25 to 40 mph range, but there could be some gusts of over 50 mph in some of the higher elevations on the Big Island.
